metadata.title: Chiral sulphonated phosphines: Part III. Rh(I)-tetrasulphonated diphosphine complex: homogeneous or heterogeneous catalyst?

Rh(I)-Tetrasulphonated Diphosphine Complex: Homogeneous or Heterogeneous Catalyst? JOURNAL OF MOLECULAR CATALYSIS LOIC LECOMTE and DENIS SINOU** Laboratoire de Synthese Asymetrique, U.A. du C.N.R.S. No. 463, Universite Lyon I, 43, bd. du 11 Novembre 1918, 69622- Villeurbanne Cedex (France) (Received February 2, 1989; accepted March 7, 1989) There has been increasing interest during the last decade in the use of water-soluble phosphines in homogeneous catalysis [2 - 5]. Organometallic complexes containing these ligands can be used in a biphasic catalytic system consisting of water and a non-miscible organic phase; this procedure offers an interesting alternative to homogeneous catalysis which allows for the recycling of the catalyst. The reduction of water-soluble substrates in water presents for example another possibility. We have studied the hydrogenation of prochiral unsaturated substrates in the presence of rhodium complexes associated with chiral sulphonated ligands cyclobutanediop (CBD) 1, skewphos 2 and chiraphos 3 [5, 6]. More interestingly, we found that recycling of the catalyst was possible without loss of enantioselectivity. During our studies, some controversies appeared in the literature about the nature of the catalytic species in the reduction in water using rhodium complexes associated with sulphonated phosphines [7 -10]. Recent studies using light scattering showed that the catalytic action was due to colloidal rhodium particles dispersed in the aqueous phase. The sulphonated phosphine used was rapidly and quantitatively oxidized. Although the rhodium precursor used by these authors and ourselves was not the same, the possible formation of colloidal rhodium particles was not in agreement with the possibility of recycling the catalyst without loss of enantioselectivity. We think that the use of chiral sulphonated phosphines could be a good method for determining the homogeneous or heterogeneous nature of the catalyst [11]. Thus we undertook a study on the influence of the rhodium complex precursor associated with these chiral sulphonated phos- phines 1 - 3 and the analogous phosphine oxides 4 - 6, on the enantioselec- tive reduction of a-acetamido acrylic acid 7, a hydrosoluble amino acid precursor, in water. *For Part II see [1]. '" Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-6102/89/$3.50 Eisevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands L22 l 2 3 / 'PAr- d.:' ^"" t^^'l Ar,P PAr, SOaNa ^CO,H H, .C02H Wc [Rh]/L* ^NHAc 2 8 The results, summarized in Table 1, showed that the e.e. obtained using [Rh(COD)Cl]2 and a tetrasulphonated phosphine as the ligand (runs TABLE l Reduction of a-acetamido acrylic acid 7 in water Run Catalyst precursor Ligand pu e.e. of 8 Config.1' (atm) (%) 1 [Rh(COD)Clh 1 1.1 21 (S) 2 [Rh(COD)Cl]2 2 6 31 (R) 3 [Rh(COD)Clh 3 6 61 (R) 4 Rhd3-3H20 1 1.1 5 (S) 5 RhCl3-3H20 2 6 15 (R) 6 RhCl3-3H20 3 6 20 (R) 7 [Rh(COD)Cl]2 4 1.1 0 8 [Rh(COD)Cl]2 560 9 [Rh(COD)Cl]2 660 10 RhCl3-3H20 4 1.1 0 ^Hligandl^Rh] = 50:1.1:1; [7] = 0.1 M; T= 25 C; in all cases the conversion was quantitative. ''Based on the value [a]^ =+66.5 (c = 2, H20) for the (R)-acetylalanine 8 [12] and confirmed by GLC analysis on the chiral column Chirasil-Val [13]. L23 l - 3) are in agreement with the values previously observed using other a- amino acid precursors as prochiral substrates. The enantioselectivity was higher with chiraphos 3 than with CBD 1. In all cases, the solution was clear, without formation of any cloudiness. In the next experiments (runs 4 - 6), we used RhC^^HiO as the rhodium precursor. Although the rate of hydrogenation was practically the same, the e.e. observed were lower: only 5%, 15% and 20% using ligands 1, 2 and 3 respectively. Some cloudiness in the solution was also observed after a few minutes. In the third set of experiments (runs 7 - 9), we used the oxides of the tetrasulphonated ligands 4, 5 and 6 associated with [Rh(COD)Cl]2. Hydro- genation occurred very rapidly and we never observed any enantioselectivity; in each run, cloudiness was observed. In the last experiment (run 10), we used RhC^ Sii^O in the presence of the oxide of CBD 4; here again reduc- tion occurred without enantioselectivity and cloudiness appeared throughout the reaction. These results clearly show that: The system [Rh(COD)Cl]2 and chiral tetrasulphonated phosphine is a typically homogeneous catalyst, in agreement with our previous results on recycling of the catalyst without loss of enantioselectivity [5,6]. the system [Rh(COD)Cl]2 and chiral tetrasulphonated phosphine oxide is a heterogenous catalyst; no enantioselectivity is observed. The same trend is found using RhCl3- 3Hft and chiral 4. the system RhCl3- 3ii^0 and chiral tetrasulphonated phosphine acts as a mixture of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalyst. Rh(III) is reduced to Rh(I) and tetrasulphonated phosphine is oxidized. Thus the system Rh(I)/ chiral phosphine at the beginning of the reduction gives some enantioselec- tivity; however the system Rh(I)/chiral phosphine oxide, which is probably colloidal, becomes more and more dominant and gives no enantioselectivity. We obtain lower overall enantioselectivity. In conclusion, our experiments show clearly that in water the system Rh(I)/sulphonated phosphine is a homogeneous catalyst. The system Rh(III/sulphonated phosphine at the beginning of the reduction gives a catalyst which is partially homogeneous and partially heterogeneous, leading finally to an entirely heterogeneous one. The system Rh(I)/sulphonated phosphine oxide is entirely heterogeneous. References 1 L. Lecomte, D. Sinou, J. Bakos, I. Toth and B. Heil, J. Organometall. Chem., (1989) in press. 2 F. Joo and Z.
